statement.tex: \\ \text{Given f(x) is defined only for }x\gt 0, \\ \text{is the following analysis correct?}

options.tex: x\gt 0\text{ is important because }\\ \log x + e^x \gt 0\text{ only for }x\gt 0.

reason.tex: \cos y \text{ is defined for all }y\in\mathbb{R}.\\ \text{But if }y = \log x + e^x,\text{ then y is defined only}\\ \text{if }\log x\text{ is defined (}e^x\text{ is not a problem either)}.\\ \text{And }\log x\text{ is defined only if }x\gt 0.

options.tex: \begin{align} \text{Let }g(x) &= \log x + e^x \\ \implies f(x) &= \cos g(x) \\ \text{and, }\dfrac{dg}{dx} &= \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right) \\ \therefore \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \dfrac{df}{dg} \cdot \dfrac{dg}{dx} \\ &= -\sin g\cdot \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right) \\ &= -\sin (\log x + e^x)\cdot \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right), x \gt 0 \end{align}

reason.tex: \begin{align} f(x) &= \cos\underbrace{(\log x + e^x)}_{g(x)} = \cos (g(x)) \\ \implies\frac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \underbrace{\frac{d}{d g(x)}\cos g(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x)}_ {\text{Chain Rule}} \end{align} \\ \text{Also, note the use of the standard results}\\ \quad \frac{d}{d\theta}\cos\theta = -\sin\theta \\ \quad \frac{d}{dy}\log y = \frac{1}{y} \\ \quad \frac{d}{dz} e^z = e^z
